{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3337967,"name":"Robert Woodhead","username":"MadOverlord","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T03:18:16.353Z","cooked":"

Our students are encountering a bizarre problem with our Mk.4 swerve modules that has us all scratching our heads.

Most of the time, everything is working fine, and the robot is completely controllable. But every so often, one of the modules will apparently randomly decide it’s a whirling dervish; the turn motor spins the module wildly, almost as if it’s getting confused and thinks it’s a drive motor.

Here is what we have been able to determine so far:

  • The issue is not limited to a single swerve module, it can happen on any of them.
  • It’s not affected by swapping the SparkMax.
  • The turn SparkMax shows an Overcurrent Flag, but we are not sure yet if this is related to the problem. We’ve tried setting the current limit to 60 and 70, to no effect. We occasionally see the same flag on other swerve SparkMaxes that don’t go wonky. We can’t find any real documentation about this flag, btw, so if anyone can point us to a good explanation of what it really means, that would be appreciated. We’re certainly not pushing the motors very hard, in any case.
  • Running auto routines seems to trigger it more often than just driving the robot around (and my gut feeling is that the longer the auto, the more likely it is to happen).
  • Redeploying code to the robot fixes the problem, until it happens again.

And just to make it even more weird, it only seems to happen in our build space; the robot performed flawlessly at our first event!

Thanks in advance for any help you can provide in tracking down and fixing this!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-20T03:18:16.353Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":132,"reads":309,"readers_count":308,"score":716.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Robert Woodhead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/canbus-logging-swerve-debug-advice/469660","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"CANBus logging / Swerve debug advice","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50408,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3337968,"name":"Basel Alghanem","username":"Basel_A","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/basel_a/{size}/65204_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T03:21:11.875Z","cooked":"
MadOverlord:

We can’t find any real documentation about this flag, btw, so if anyone can point us to a good explanation of what it really means, that would be appreciated. We’re certainly not pushing the motors very hard, in any case.

First off, here’s an email from REV support from four days ago

The Over Current Fault happens when the SPARK MAX reaches its secondary current limit, also known as the “Current Chop” limit. This limit is set by default to 115A (but can be changed), and it will “chop” the output by turning it on and off very rapidly to protect the controller and reduce the output current. Even though the Smart Current Limit is set lower than this (the default setting is 80A) this limit can still be reached when a high-load event on the motor results in a current spike that is too fast for the Smart Current Limit to react to.

Without seeing code…

Have you done anything to narrow down the cause? Have you used FRCWebComponents/AdvantageScope/etc to see the swerve state/command graphically?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-20T03:21:30.276Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":252,"readers_count":251,"score":60.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/3","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3337974,"name":"Basel Alghanem","username":"Basel_A","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/basel_a/{size}/65204_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T03:29:07.724Z","cooked":"

This sounds like it might be related to usage of WPILib’s SwerveModuleState optimize function, which has some brief docs here. Maybe there’s an offset difference between the module’s position and the one it’s considering in the optimize call.

It could also depend on how you’ve configured wrapping on your steering controller (whether it’s a WPILib PID Controller, SparkMax onboard PID Controller, or something else). I’m currently looking into the onboard controller’s wrapping behavior because of a potentially similar issue, but haven’t come to any conclusions yet.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-20T03:30:47.942Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":243,"readers_count":242,"score":88.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Basel Alghanem","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/kinematics-and-odometry/swerve-drive-kinematics.html#module-angle-optimization","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Swerve Drive Kinematics — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12479,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3338033,"name":"Andy Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T05:00:26.205Z","cooked":"

If I had to guess, the SPARK Max is losing power and restarting, causing it to lose it’s inversion setting. If the motor is supposed to be inverted but is not, it will spin out of control because the error will get larger when it should be getting smaller.

When the problem occurs, you could connect the REV Hardware Client and check if the inversion settings are still correct.

Since you didn’t share your code, I cannot see how you are setting the inversion, so I’ll share our best practices for configuring SPARK Max motor controllers. We always call restoreFactoryDefaults() to clear out any previous settings, then we apply the configuration (including inversion), and finally we can burnFlash() so the settings persist through power cycle.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-20T05:00:26.205Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":208,"readers_count":207,"score":71.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Andy Gasser","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44380,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/5","custom_user_title":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3338103,"name":"Robert Woodhead","username":"MadOverlord","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T10:38:17.890Z","cooked":"

Thank you all for the helpful replies, you have given our students some things to look into at today’s meeting.

I will post an update with what we learn this evening.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-20T10:38:17.890Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":169,"readers_count":168,"score":33.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Robert Woodhead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50408,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3338362,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T15:16:23.368Z","cooked":"

Also, it’s a good idea to reset any PID controllers or anything else that has any state in both Auto/TeleopInit. The specifics are very different if you are doing the control on the SPARK MAX, or on the rio. These can accumulate a lot of “windup” while you are disabled.

If you are doing control on the SPARK MAX, it might take a power cycle or some type of explicit reset to restore things. If you are doing this on the rio, “Restart Robot Code” should normally clear things – but it’s possible even this would not, depending on the code.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-20T15:16:23.368Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":151,"readers_count":150,"score":30.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Allen Nuttle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14283,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3339362,"name":"Robert Woodhead","username":"MadOverlord","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-21T11:30:53.166Z","cooked":"

Here are the results of last night’s testing:

The swerve modules were not inverted, but the students added burnFlash() calls in any case.

The better logging of the swerve state that was suggested didn’t happen for a variety of reasons (mostly because the students were also working on a bunch of other things in the mad rush before our next competition this weekend).

In any case, the problem did not crop up again, and we were starting to breathe a bit easier, when, close to the end of our practice time… @&$&@*!!

It happened during teleop and the robot was being driven, how shall I put it, “spiritedly”. The driver reported a burst of CAN errors but the log didn’t get preserved due to a miscommunication so I can’t report exactly what happened.

Plugging directly into a Sparkmax, all the sparkmaxes were showing they’d seen a CAN fault, and the misbehaving turn SparkMax was showing an overcurrent fault.

We cleared the SparkMax faults, re-enabled the robot (wheels on chocks, so no load on the wheels) and ran the swerve system for another second. Plugging back into the Sparkmaxes showed that the turn Sparkmax had suffered another overcurrent event, which is confusing since the wheel is free to spin with no impediment except gear friction.

We then proceeded to troubleshoot CAN by doing wiggle tests on the wiring to try and find a flaky connection, and here is where it gets very weird.

We did not find any problematic CAN wiring, but at some points in the process the CAN bus was disconnected at various quick-connects.

Then, when we reconnected the CAN bus and re-enabled the robot, the problem was still present – on the OTHER turn motor on the same side of the robot!!!

That’s right – just wiggle-testing and breaking/reconnecting the CAN bus caused the problem to jump from one turn motor to the other. The formerly misbehaving motor was now working correctly.

Redeploying the code cleared the problem, as always. I am leaning towards this being something weird inside a library because we’re not doing anything fancy, just a standard WPILib Swerve configuration.

The only things on the CAN bus are SparkMaxes, CANcoders and a CANdle for controlling a LED panel.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-21T11:30:53.166Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":142,"readers_count":141,"score":33.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Robert Woodhead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50408,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3339393,"name":"Brandon","username":"bmcdonnell41","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-21T12:32:08.795Z","cooked":"

Sounds like a CAN problem. I’ve seen similar behavior when using these to connect CAN wires together:

CTR Electronics

CAN Connector (5 Pack)

CAN Connector

Price: USD 19.99

The metal pins on the back were grounding the wires to the robots metal frame.

What are you using to connect your wires together?

Can you check if there is continuity between can wires and frame or ground?

That kind of problem can be intermittent with wires jiggling while driving.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-21T12:32:08.795Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":123,"readers_count":122,"score":39.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Brandon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://store.ctr-electronics.com/can-connector-5-pack/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"CAN Connector (5 Pack) - CTR Electronics","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50408,"username":"MadOverlord","name":"Robert Woodhead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55131,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3339444,"name":"Robert Woodhead","username":"MadOverlord","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-21T13:44:00.681Z","cooked":"

We are using wagos and wago-style din-rail connectors for the canbus connections. All the canbus wires are terminated with crimped ferrules.

I will put testing for a short-to-chassis on the to-do list.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-21T13:44:00.681Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":111,"readers_count":110,"score":27.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Robert Woodhead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":55131,"username":"bmcdonnell41","name":"Brandon","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/35a633/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50408,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3340163,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-21T22:44:53.180Z","cooked":"

Without knowing how/where you control the steering motors, it’s hard to be very specific. Details, links to code are best. Do you use custom code, or one of the swerve libraries?

Think about what happens if you lose data from a steering angle sensor – will something stop the steering motors, or will they run up to maximum speed and keep running? You can test this scenario.

The motors should disable if they are not getting any CAN traffic, but this could take a little time. They will continue to execute the last set they saw until they disable. This doesn’t sound like what you are seeing.

I’ve seen this happen infrequently on robots with different drive motors and motor controllers, different sensors, different S/W, etc. Your case does sound strange, but try to remain open to different theories and to keep collecting data.

This used to occasionally happen on swerve robots for the team I currently mentor, with all the control logic running on the rio – and using WPILib code for some of it. We got it to go away for good by being sure we reset our drive subsystem any time we came out of disabled state. And, we made sure resetting the drive system stopped the motors, reset sensors, PID controllers, etc. At the end of the day, for that codebase and series of robots, it was a S/W issue.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-21T22:44:53.180Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":106,"readers_count":105,"score":21.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Allen Nuttle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14283,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3340445,"name":"Robert Woodhead","username":"MadOverlord","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T10:45:09.921Z","cooked":"

Again, thanks for all the helpful suggestions. We found one more potentially problematic CANbus connection last night (someone forgot to crimp ferrules on the ends of a couple of wires, and wiggling them would occasionally cause a flash of red on the CANcoders), and we’ll implement further software precautions as per Nuttle’s suggestions.

Our programming lead intends to post some code after this weekend’s event.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-22T10:45:09.921Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":95,"readers_count":94,"score":34.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Robert Woodhead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50408,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3341003,"name":"Jared Van Horn","username":"CuteRedpandas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cuteredpandas/{size}/243322_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T23:06:48.097Z","cooked":"

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-22T23:07:02.100Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":86,"readers_count":85,"score":17.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Jared Van Horn","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51417,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Alum/NJIT Student"},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/13","custom_user_title":"Alum/NJIT Student","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3342504,"name":"Robert Woodhead","username":"MadOverlord","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T07:00:13.448Z","cooked":"

Update after our second competition. We did not get a spinny wheel anomaly (as far as we could tell), but we did get another weird one – we would lose control of our arm, and only our arm; the rest of the robot worked OK.

The logs showed stale updates from one, and only one, swerve module cancoder, followed by various canbus devices going offline.

A very close examination of the offending cancoder revealed some broken wire strands that could potentially cause intermittent shorts. After swapping out the device, the robot performed properly for the rest of the event.

Hopefully that was the Root of All Canbus Evil and we shall not see its like again at States.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-03-25T07:00:13.448Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":76,"readers_count":75,"score":35.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Robert Woodhead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50408,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352791,"name":"Robert Woodhead","username":"MadOverlord","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-05T09:19:53.670Z","cooked":"

A further update (and possible resolution!):

After returning home from the competition, we continued to be beset by issues related to losing control of the arm. It was particularly frustrating because the problem would, at times, fix itself without touching the robot – just looking at it sternly would sometimes cause things to start working again!

Much tugging (both of wires and hair) and canbus checking ensued, to no avail. But then we realized that the canbus error messages were isolated to the last two devices on the bus (before being terminated at the PDH, which is also a canbus device) – and the main climb arm motor was the last device.

Swapping the order of devices on the canbus caused the issue to move; it was indeed apparently positional.

At this point, we made 3 changes in an attempt to isolate the cause:

  • We removed the climb motors from the canbus, to check if the problem was # of devices.
  • We removed the CANdle LED device, since it was a new component we hadn’t previously used.
  • We disabled the termination resistor on the PDH and used an external termination resistor.

Subsequent to these three changes, we encountered no canbus anomalies. We then restored the climb motors to the canbus, and again, no problems were encountered.

Finally, we reconnected the CANdle, and again, no problems were encountered.

Therefore, our current thinking is that there is some sort of fault in the PDH canbus termination that was causing communications problems with the devices closest to it on the bus.

Interestingly, when the PDH is unpowered, the resistance across the canbus terminals is the expected 120 ohms (with nothing else connected to the PDH canbus terminals), but when power is applied, it goes up into the mega-ohm range. I have no idea if this is normal, but both our PDH devices exhibit this behavior.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-05T09:19:53.670Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":12,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":97.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Robert Woodhead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50408,"username":"MadOverlord","name":"Robert Woodhead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50408,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352912,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-05T14:28:28.940Z","cooked":"

Random curiosity, at any point were your can wires exposed and could have touched another exposed power wire or the frame?

I have seen teams where i told them that “look, all of these connectors are going to short bc they will touch the frame, you can fix this by using different connectors later but now you should really put electrical tape over them.” and most of their gremlins were warded off.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-05T14:28:39.864Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":41,"readers_count":40,"score":18.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50408,"username":"MadOverlord","name":"Robert Woodhead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/16","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352919,"name":"Tom","username":"Zook","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zook/{size}/252720_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-05T14:47:12.136Z","cooked":"
MadOverlord:

but when power is applied, it goes up into the mega-ohm range

Don’t use a digital multimeter on a powered circuit to measure resistance!

On the unpowered circuit, the multimeter will effectively measure the least resistance between the two leads. If the rest of the PDH is an open circuit, the DMM will measure the terminal resistor value.

On a powered circuit, the small current the multimeter is trying to pass through the resistor is going to get mixed with the other currents. Too big of a voltage between the leads and it looks like R = V/I is a HUGE V over the small I. So, mega ohms.

At least that’s my understanding of it!

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-05T14:48:06.854Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":39,"readers_count":38,"score":77.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":459394,"topic_slug":"suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules","display_username":"Tom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14980,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4276 nice mentor"},"post_url":"/t/suffering-from-suddenly-spinning-swerve-modules/459394/17","custom_user_title":"4276 nice mentor","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352921,"name":"Robert Woodhead","username":"MadOverlord","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-05T14:50:29.649Z","cooked":"

I wouldn’t 100% rule it out (at this point, I wouldn’t 100% rule out the existence of evil shop gremlins being the root cause!) but we used wagos or din-rail wagos for all the connections, all the wires had ferrules crimped on, and in the few places where the wires went through the frame the holes were protected with 3-d printed grommets. We also checked for shorts to the frame and never found one.

It is possible, of course, that the fault was in the terminal canbus pair connecting to the PDH; the rewiring done for the final test replaced that length of wiring. However, if memory serves, we’d already replaced it once out of pure paranoia and the problem persisted.

Once the season is over, we will revert back to the problematic configuration and see if the problem crops up again. It would be nice to have a definitive diagnosis.
